channel.title: Entity Framework on Baywet's blog
channel.description: Recent content in Entity Framework on Baywet's blog

item.title: Old English posts migrated to this blog
item.description:
Everything is in the title. My French blog has been running for more than six years now (gee, I’m getting old).

From 2013 to 2014, before I decided to open an English dedicated blog, I was posting every blog entry in English and in French.

Over time it got messy for both communities so I decided to open this blog. But I couldn’t move the old content to this new blog without having to spend hours doing so.

item.title: Controlled update of SQL databases Schema with Entity Framework Code First in a continous delivery process
item.description:
Introduction

Entity Framework is a well-known technology in the ORM domain for the .NET world.

Note: Object Relational Mapping, this is the part between data persistence unit and some more “high level” code.

When you start a new entity framework project you have a few different ways to do it, one of which being “code first”. It means our code will drive the SQL Schema evolution (which simplifies a lot of things and allows you to focus on business and not technical implementation).

item.title: Entity Framework and dataContext reference for a web application
item.description:
When using the entity framework with a data context we often have this problematic:

What’s the best between performance and simplicity of usage or scalability?

(no? you do not ask yourself that kind of existential question?)

Here is a little explanation :

Static instance

In this first case you wrote a static reference to the context. Sometimes you also add some lazy loading and/or disposal management in global.asax (application end event)
